profile_data.summary:
Research | Algorithm Design and Analysis | Machine Learning | Deep Learning | Information Retrieval | Forecasting | Gen-AI

- Working with the Applied AI Science team. Our vision is for knowledge operations work across Worldwide Amazon Stores (WWAS) to be automated, enabling our teams to focus on the most creative and critical decision-making work, while raising the quality bar for outcomes. Our mission is to build reusable solutions that delight organizations in WWAS who leverage AI with the goal of making knowledge operations work more efficient.

- Worked on Shipments Per Route (SPR) forecasting problem using Physics-assisted Machine Learning for Last Mile Planning Science team

- Worked on task decomposition and planning using LLM and IR methods (RAG) and search methods (MCTS, BFS, DFS)

- Worked on building AutoML solutions @Amazon scale thereby enabling non-tech users to self-serve build, train, deploy and maintain ML models (for business policy driven use cases) in production that operate on products hosted in the Amazon catalog. 

- Worked in the area of Robust Learning at catalog scale.

- Worked on Batch mode Target-Aware Active Learning at catalog scale.

- Worked on devising Machine Learning solutions for several problems related to Focused Web Crawlers.

- Developed expertise in content/structure/position based classification/characterization of web documents using both classical machine learning and modern day deep learning techniques with strong emphasis on CV, NLP.

- Prior experience of working in Causal analysis of time series using Granger Causal models.
profile_data.headline: Sr. Applied Scientist @ Amazon | Applied AI Science | Ex-Last Mile Planning Science | Ex-CPP AI | Ex-SM Crawler Strategies | Ex-Shell Labs | Ex-IISc

experience.description:
I have worked in the area of Machine Learning with Prof. Arnab Bhattacharyya in the department of Computer Science and Automation (CSA), IISc. Here is a brief abstract of the two problems that i worked upon :
1. BoPGD : Stable and Scalable feature selection under Multicollinearity
We consider sparse regression under a high-dimensional linear model with strongly correlated
variables, situations which cannot be handled well using many existing model selection algorithms
(e.g - Lasso). We propose a new feature selection algorithm which cluster the features ﬁrst based
on their sample correlation and do subsequent sparse estimation using a bootstrapped variant of
the projected gradient descent method with projection on the non-convex L_{0} ball. The algorithm is stable, consistent, scalable and computationally efficient in comparison with Lasso and other convex relaxation based feature selection algorithms.

2. Temporal Lag discovery for Causal Inference on Time Series Data
Discovering causal relationships, beyond mere correlation, is widely recognized as a fundamental problem. The blend of Graphical modeling of temporal data based on the concept of Granger Causality along with model selection techniques, such as Lasso, enables eﬃcient discovery of a “sparse" subset of causal variables in high dimensional settings. However, these temporal Granger causal methods use an input parameter, the maximum time lag. This parameter is the maximum gap in time between the occurrence of the output phenomenon and the causal input stimulus. In many situations of interest, the maximum time lag is not known, and indeed, ﬁnding the range of causal eﬀects is an important problem. In this work, we propose and evaluate a data-driven and computationally eﬃcient method for Granger causality inference in the vector auto-regression model without foreknowledge of the maximum time lag.
experience.title: Research Student

publications.name: RT2S: A Framework For Learning with Noisy Labels
publications.description: We introduce Robust Training with Trust Scores (RT2S), a framework to train machine learning classifiers with potentially noisy labels. RT2S calculates a trust score for each training sample, which indicates the quality of its corresponding label. These trust scores are employed as sample weights during training and optionally during threshold optimization. The trust scores are generated from two sources: (i) the model’s confidence in the observed label, leveraging out-of-fold prediction scores to detect anomalous labels in the training data, and (ii) the probability of the correct label, ascertained by a Large Language Model with the ability to identify biased label noise. We evaluate RT2S by training machine learning models on 6 product classification datasets that utilize low-quality labels generated by a rule-based classification engine acting as a surrogate labeler. Our experimental findings indicate that RT2S outperforms all baselines, and achieves an average accuracy improvement of 4.38% (max 7.18%) over rule-based classifiers in particular.

publications.name: TAAL: Target-Aware Active Learning
publications.publisher: Amazon Machine Learning Conference (AMLC) - Aug 31, 2022 | ECNLP 6 Workshop @KDD2023 - Jun 26, 2023
publications.description: Pool-based active learning techniques have had success producing multi-class classifiers that achieve high accuracy with fewer labels compared to random labeling. However, in an industrial setting where we have class-level business targets to achieve (e.g., 95% recall at 95% precision for each class), active learning techniques continue to acquire labels for classes that have already met their targets, thus consuming unnecessary manual annotations. We address this problem by proposing a framework called Target-Aware Active Learning (TAAL) that converts any query strategy into its target-aware variant by leveraging the gap between each class’ current estimated accuracy and its corresponding business target. We empirically show that target-aware variants of state-of-the-art active learning techniques achieve business targets faster on 2 open-source image classification datasets and 2 proprietary product classification datasets.

publications.name: Visually guided Template Extraction and Language Agnostic Classification of web pages
publications.publisher: Amazon Computer Vision Conference (ACVC) 2020 | 1st Amazon ASCS Applied Science Workshop (ASC2W) Q1 2020
publications.description: Classification of web pages from e-commerce websites into product, browse, or, others is essential for catalog expansion and enrichment. Many systems rely on this content to identify selection gaps and back-fill catalog attributes. However, it is a hard problem to identify such pages with very high accuracy due to varying layouts across websites which are distributed among diverse marketplaces and language zones. Most of the existing approaches use handcrafted features derived from the HTML document which either fail to generalize at scale or require a huge corpus of training data across different dimensions like language, region, product categories, etc. In this work, we propose a technique that uses no language specific text features, instead using the DOM, CSSOM and render-tree attributes of a web page to generate a simplified template image which is then fed through a Deep CNN trained to do fine-grained classification. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by training a ResNet-34 network using the transfer learning setup on a corpus of ≈ 4K template images from English language websites and achieve ≥ 95% accuracy in multi-class classification task which include other language pages too.

publications.name: Efficient Crawling of E-Commerce Websites for Product Discovery
publications.publisher: 1st Amazon ASCS Applied Science Workshop (ASC2W) Q1 2020
publications.description: Crawling web pages to discover new products poses a unique problem of indefinite (unbounded) crawls in some e-commerce websites because of the combinatorial explosion of filtering options available on product listings. The current approach to overcome this problem has been to have manually written configurations for every such problematic website and direct the crawler away from the filter URLs. In this paper, we propose and evaluate a website specific approach to detect filter URLs that can be discarded from our crawl without affecting product discovery. More precisely, we present a sampling strategy that aims at maximizing identification of different URL patterns from a highly skewed corpus, followed by an automatic feature selection approach to train a discriminative classifier using very small number of training samples (≈ 100 URLs). We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in carefully avoiding filter URLs without hampering product discovery, by running crawls on 5 different websites.

publications.name: Sauron - One model to extract them all
publications.description: Extracting product attribute information from e-commerce websites is one of the critical tasks for catalog expansion and enrichment. In this work, we propose ways to apply instance based nearest neighbour algorithms that given a just few samples from a website for an attribute, uses them cleverly to discover attribute values for rest of the products in the website. More precisely, we propose an embedding driven approach to find similarities between instances and these embeddings are learned contextually in an unsupervised way. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in finding product variants, product attributes and extracting key-value pairs from specifications table.

publications.name: URL Based Multi-Class Page Classification
publications.publisher: Search Workshop, Amazon Machine Learning Conference (AMLC)
publications.description: In this work, we discuss an architecture of URL representation followed by classification that can be trained at website-specific level to achieve high precision and recall on multiple labels. We propose a novel method of distributed representations of URL through contextual token embeddings that captures the URL conventions used within a website. The rich URL representations allow us to train simple classifiers with about 50-100 labeled pages per website and yet achieve high performance.

publications.name: Focused Crawling of Product pages from an e-commerce website
publications.description: In this work we introduce a novel and systematic approach to efficiently crawl all product pages from an e-commerce website. We propose a methodology where the crawler progressively learns to prioritize the relevant URLs that lead to product pages. It employs supervised and unsupervised learning techniques coupled with statistical modeling to learn the nature of relevant URLs. To elaborate, we devised strategies to initially explore the website, then learn the regularities in the website structure and finally exploit them to find all product pages. Finally, the results from real world websites indicate the approach discovers all product pages by crawling ∼ 45% fewer URLs compared to a full website crawl.

publications.name: Temporal Lag estimation and Granger Causality on time series
publications.publisher: [Paper was retracted by the authors from Proceedings of the 23rd ACM SIGKDD International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining, August 2017, Workshop on Mininig and Learning from Time Series (MiLeTS 2017) - Travel Funding issue]
publications.description: Inferring causal relationships among features generated as time series is an important problem with many applications. For high dimensional data, causal inference becomes a challenging task due to the curse of dimensionality. Graphical modeling of temporal data based on the concept of “Granger Causality” has gained much attention in this context. The blend of Granger methods along with model selection techniques such as Lasso, enables efficient discovery of a “sparse” subset of causal variables in high dimensional settings.  These temporal causal inference methods use an input parameter, L, the maximum time lag, also called the max lag. This parameter is the maximum gap in time between the occurrence of the output phenomenon and the causal input stimulus. However, in many situations of interest, the maximum time lag is unknown, and indeed, finding the range of causal effects is an important problem. In this work, we propose and evaluate a data-driven and computationally efficient method for Granger causality inference in time series without foreknowledge of the maximum time lag parameter. We present two algorithms here viz. Lasso Granger++ and Group Lasso Granger++ which alongside inferring the hypothesis feature causal graph, also estimates a value of max-lag by balancing the trade-off between “goodness of fit” and “model complexity”.

publications.name: Machine Learning and Statistical Analysis for Materials Science: Stability and Transferability of Fingerprint Descriptors and Chemical Insights
publications.publisher: ACS Publications : The Journal of Chemistry of Materials
publications.description: In the paradigm of virtual high-throughput screening for materials, we have developed a semiautomated workflow or “recipe” that can help a material scientist to start from a raw data set of materials with their properties and descriptors, build predictive models, and draw insights into the governing mechanism. We demonstrate our recipe, which employs machine learning tools and statistical analysis, through application to a case study leading to identification of descriptors relevant to catalysts for CO2 electroreduction, starting from a published database of 298 catalyst alloys. At the heart of our methodology lies the Bootstrapped Projected Gradient Descent (BoPGD) algorithm, which has significant advantages over commonly used machine learning (ML) and statistical analysis (SA) tools such as the regression coefficient shrinkage-based method (LASSO) or artificial neural networks: (a) it selects descriptors with greater stability and transferability, with a goal to understand the chemical mechanism rather than fitting data, and (b) while being effective for smaller data sets such as in the test case, it employs clustering of descriptors to scale far more efficiently to large size of descriptor sets in terms of computational speed. In addition to identifying the descriptors that parametrize the d-band model of catalysts for CO2 reduction, we predict work function to be an essential and relevant descriptor. Based on this result, we propose a modification of the d-band model that includes the chemical effect of work function, and show that the resulting predictive model gives the binding energy of CO to catalyst fairly accurately. Since our scheme is general and particularly efficient in reducing a set of large number of descriptors to a minimal one, we expect it to be a versatile tool in obtaining chemical insights into complex phenomena and development of predictive models for design of materials.
